column3: The factory would use various methods to hide the spoiled meat. If the smoked hams were found to be spoiled, a white-hot iron would be inserted into the hole to render the meat safe for consumption."

column3: Some of the ways the factory would cover up spoiled meat were: If the meat was spoiled and the odor was bad they would pickle it to hide the order. "Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad. Formerly these had been sold as “Number Three Grade,” but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. " (2). If the whole ham was spoiled it was cut up and mixed with half a ton of other meat.  "It was only when the whole ham was spoiled that it came into the department of Elzbieta. Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions- a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference." (3)Their were also many other things done to the meat some of those being: chemicals added, gelatin for color, rat poop taken out of it among many other things.

column3: According to Aristotle, there are 3 effects in tragedy. He explains all three in the following paragraphs. In paragraph two he says a complex plan would be more effective as it will enact emotions. "A plot of this kind would, doubtless satisfy the moral sense, but inspire neither pity nor fear; for pity is aroused by unmerited misfortune, fear by the misfortune of a man like ourselves," (Paragraph 2). In Paragraph three he mentions a well-constructed tragedy to be single rather than double. "Hense they are in error who censure Euripides just because he follows this principle in his plays, many of which end unhappily. It is, as we have said, the right ending." (Paragraph 3). In Paragraph four he ends the plan with a perfect tragedy saying, It has an opposite catapsphrphe for the good and bad. "The pleasure, however, thence derived is not the true tragic pleasure. It is proper rather to Comedy, where those who, in the piece, are the deadliest enemies." (Paragraph 4).
column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage:  According to Aristotle, tragedy had three effects. First, he emphasized that the complex plan should be effective because it stimulates emotions. He explained that a well-constructed tragedy should be single and not double because the two have different effects. Finally, he argued that the pleasure derived from tragedy should be more valuable and authentic rather than the superficial pleasure found in comedies.

column3: The first element of an ideal tragedy is that it should strike pity and fear into the audience. This is because the tragedy should never satisfy the audience's moral sense. The second element is that the change of fortune in a tragedy should never go from bad to good, instead, it should go from good to bad. This connects to the first element as it is supposed to strike pity and fear into the audience instead of satisfying their moral sense. The 3rd element is the type of tragedy. A poet should not let his audience guide the tragedy and instead should do the opposite to gain the true tragic pleasure.
column4: A tragedy should initially strike a chord with the audience by eliciting a sense of pity and fear. It should never end satisfying the audience's emotional desires. Likewise, the transformation of fate in a tragedy should change from good to bad. This play on opposites leads to a sense of heightened emotional impact, making the audience feel a greater sense of terror and suspense. Lastly, a tragedy should be structured in a way that allows the poet to retain control of the audience and guide them through a series of emotions.

column3: The structure of the Egyptian government was basically a dictatorship, with the pharaoh at the top position, mainly because people believed they were gods in human form. Their right-hand men were viziers, who ensured that taxes were paid. After them were the nobles and priests, with nobles holding government posts and "priests were responsible for pleasing the gods". Next were soldiers who, of course, fought in wars. Finally we have the farmers, peasants, and slaves who all share the weakest power in the Egyptian government.
column4: The power structure of the Egyptian government resembled a dictatorship, with the pharaoh occupying the top position. The right-hand men, or viziers, held significant influence through taxation duties. Nobles and priests held key positions in the government, with nobles holding executive and legislative responsibilities. Soldiers participated in military efforts, while farmers, peasants, and slaves collectively had the weakest power within the government.

column3: The first element of an ideal tragedy is the character needs to be neither good nor evil but made a mistake that leads to his downfall and things go from good to bad. The second element of an ideal tragedy is to make the ending seem like all hope is lost and the character never redeems him/herself.  The third element of an ideal tragedy is that the plot should be well-constructed and not overly confusing or following too many plot lines.
column4: An ideal tragedy involves a character whose flaws lead to a tragic outcome, culminating in a sense of hopelessness and the protagonist's inability to redeem themselves. Each play must have a well-structured plot that avoids confusion and adheres to a single overarching storyline.

column3: Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose. In the pickling of hams they had an ingenious apparatus, by which they saved time and increased the capacity of the plant—a machine consisting of a hollow needle attached to a pump; by plunging this needle into the meat and working with his foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds. And yet, in spite of this, there would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them. To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor—a process known to the workers as “giving them thirty per cent.” Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad. Formerly these had been sold as “Number Three Grade,” but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. After this invention there was no longer Number One, Two, and Three Grade—there was only Number One Grade. The packers were always originating such schemes—they had what they called “boneless hams,” which were all the odds and ends of pork stuffed into casings; and “California hams,” which were the shoulders, with big knuckle joints, and nearly all the meat cut out; and fancy “skinned hams,” which were made of the oldest hogs, whose skins were so heavy and coarse that no one would buy them—that is, until they had been cooked and chopped fine and labeled “head cheese!”
column4: Jonas informed them that the pickled meat sometimes became sour and that they would rub it with soda to neutralize the smell and sell it on the school cafeteria free-lunch counters. They listed numerous chemical marvels performed on meat, including an ingenious apparatus for increasing the size of the plant by injecting a needle into the meat. Despite this, they encountered spoiled hams that were highly pungent and unpleasant to consume. To address this issue, they utilized a stronger, stronger pickle to eliminate the odor, which caused the meat to be referred to as "Number Three Grade." However, even after processing, some hams remained spoiled, prompting workers to refine their methods and come up with a new and improved method that replaced the old "Number Three Grade" system.

column3: The ideal tragedy should imitate actions that excite pity and fear. Pity is aroused by unmerited misfortune, fear by the misfortune of a man like ourselves. A well-constructed plot should, therefore, be single in its issue, rather than double as some maintain. It should come about as the result, not of vice, but of some great error or frailty, in a character either such as we have described, or better rather than worse. A tragedy, then, to be perfect according to the rules of art, should be of this construction. Hence they are in error who censure Euripides just because he follows this principle in his plays, many of which end unhappily.
column4: The ideal tragic play should evoke a mix of pity and fear in the audience. This emotional response is based on the premise that tragic events evoke a sense of undeserved suffering and the threat of hardship for someone like our protagonist. A well-crafted tragedy should have a single central focus, like a single thread that leads to its climax. Not only should it result from the actions of a character but from an underlying flaw or mistake, rather than being built on vice or weakness, to achieve its perfection. Tragic plays, therefore

column3: The Jungle by Upton Sinclair explains several processes by which violations of the meatpacking happened. Meat factory workers would prepare rotten and diseased meat with better meats. The unpleasant pork fat and beef scraps will be packed or canned like chicken. Many of these meats would be chopped up to make sausage. "For it was the custom, as they found, whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage." (Paragraph 1, lines 5-7).  "It was only when the whole ham was spoiled that it came into the department of Elzbieta. Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions- a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference. There was never the least attention paid to what was cut up for sausage; there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white – it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption." (Paragraph 3, lines 34-39). "There would be meat that had tumbled out on the floor, in the dirt and sawdust, where the workers had tramped and spit uncounted billions of consumption germs. There would be meat stored in great piles in rooms, and the water from leaky roofs would drip over it, and thousands of rats would race about on it. It was too dark in these storage places to see well, but a man could run his hand over these piles of meat and sweep off handfuls of the dried dung of rats. These rats were nuisances, and the packers would put poisoned bread out for them; they would die, and then rats, bread, and meat would go into the hoppers together. " (Paragraph 4, lines 40-45).
column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage:  The Jungle by Upton Sinclair described several techniques used by meatpacking workers to waste and dispose of spoiled and diseased meat. Among these techniques was the preparation of rotten and diseased meat by mixing with better meats or packing or canning like chicken. The workers also chopped up spoiled meat to create sausage.  Most of the spoiled meats were sent to the department of Elzbieta. There, they were cut up by workers with a frequency of 2,000 revolutions per minute and mixed with other meat, so that no odor could distinguish one type of meat from another. The workers paid little attention to the sausage-making process, and the finished sausages were always low in quality and often smelled rancid.  Undead meat was stored in large piles, often in water-logged conditions, and was infested with numerous rats who caused havoc in these storage locations. The workers would sometimes feed poison to rats, who would then die and contaminate the meat, bread, and even other meats.

column3: With the help of Sinclar and Jonas, the shameful conditions that once occurred in Chicago's meatpacking industry had been caught. Specifically, Sinclar reveals the immoral actions that transpired in an attempt to cover up spoiled meat.  Sinclar indicates that the factories covered up spoiled meat through masking odors, reusing rejected meat, and combining normal meat and rat meat simply out of pure laziness. For example, Sinclar states that the meat "would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption." That quote in itself explains one of the many attempts in which the factories hid their corrupt techniques. Additionally, Sinclar incorporates vivid and descriptive imagery to illustrate the masked meatpacking process. Sinclar states, "There would be meat stored in great piles in rooms, and the water from leaky roofs would drip over it, and thousands of rats would race about on it. It was too dark in these storage places to see well, but a man could run his hand over these piles of meat and sweep off handfuls of the dried dung of rats." The explanation regarding the rats and the leaky rooms emphasizes the feeble conditions located in the specific offices. Another way in which the factory workers hid their spoiled meat was by supplementing odorous pickles to the most spoiled portions of meat. This was done in an attempt to mask the stench of the meat. Overall, Sinclar uses tone and imagery to illustrate the corrupt business done by meatpacking workers.
column4: Rewritten Passage:  With the assistance of Sinclar and Jonas, the appalling conditions prevalent within Chicago's meatpacking industry were exposed. Sinclar's exposé focuses on the unethical actions undertaken by factory workers to conceal the realities of the industry. Specifically, Sinclar reveals the deceptive practices of masking odors, reusing rejected meat, and merging normal meat with rat meat as mere laziness. One notable instance cited by Sinclar is the disposal of spoiled meat by stuffing it into hoppers and later making it part of home food. This process illustrates the dishonest and deceitful tactics employed by employees to maintain profits.  Further, Sinclar utilizes vivid imagery to depict the horrors of the meatpacking environment. He describes "meat stored in great piles in rooms, surrounded by water that would drip over the meat and attract rat waste. Thousands of rats scurried around the storage areas, adding to the dismal scene." This scene serves as a stark reminder of the unsanitary and inhumane conditions within the meatpacking plants.  Ultimately, Sinclar's tone and imagery effectively convey the extent of the unethical practices within the meatpacking industry and expose the corrupt behavior of factory workers.

column3: 3 elements of an ideal tragedy, as described by Aristole. Element 1 is as stated from the text, " A perfect tragedy should, as we have seen, be arranged not on the simple but on the complex plan. ". Element 2 from the text, "It should, moreover, imitate actions which excite pity and fear, this being the distinctive mark of tragic imitation."Lastly element 3 from the text, "It follows plainly, in the first place, that the change of fortune presented must not be the spectacle of a virtuous man brought from prosperity to adversity: for this moves neither pity nor fear; it merely shocks us. Nor, again, that of a bad man passing from adversity to prosperity: for nothing can be more alien to the spirit of Tragedy".
column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage:  "Aristole defines tragedy through three elements: the complex plan, the evocative and fearsome actions, and the absence of a spectacle of virtue and adversity. Each element contributes to the overall understanding of tragedy, highlighting the power and impact of tragedy."

column4: The passage describes a hierarchy of jobs in the ancient world.    First, deities and goddesses emerged. Then, the Pharaoh, like a god but human, ascended the throne. Next came the nobles, responsible for shaping the governance of the country, and the priests, tasked with pleasing the gods. Following were the vassals, who held the responsibility of managing the lands and ensuring taxes were paid. The scribes meticulously kept detailed records of the government's affairs. Skilled workers, including doctors and artisans, formed the middle class. Merchants and storekeepers played significant roles in facilitating trade and commerce. Lastly, slaves and farmers formed

column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage:  In many states, the meat industry adheres to strict regulations regarding preparation and distribution to ensure the safety and freshness of their products. However, in 1906 the Chicago industry operated in the opposite direction. A factory in Chicago employed various strategies to utilize spoiled meat, including canning, sauting, pickling, and smoking. The resulting products showcased a diverse array of meat parts, some spoiled but still edible, others with slight spoilage and were transformed into sausages, pickles, or smoked.  Due to the varied methods employed to fix spoiled meat, one of the most popular techniques was pickling. Jonas suggests that the sourness of the pickled meat was often perceived as a sign of spoilage, requiring customers to add soda to alleviate the taste.

column3: The book " The Jungle' expresses the unsanitary and dangerous life of the worker's experiences in meat factories. In paragraph 4 it reveals a terrible thing which was, "These rats were nuisances, and the packers would put poisoned bread out for them; they would die, and then rats, bread, and meat would go into the hoppers together... there were things that went into the sausage in comparison with which a poisoned rat was a tidbit." This expresses how the business didn't care what was giving to the customers and only worried about profit. The workers got so used to the disgusting job that they didn't even flinch to rats getting put in the meat.  This shows that the meat industry was a terrible problem that needed to be solved.
column4: The book "The Jungle" is a scathing examination of the unsanitary and dangerous working conditions of factory workers. In paragraph 4, it details a disturbing incident that illustrates the disregard the business had for its customers. The passage explains that the workers were routinely fed poisoned bread and allowed to eat leftovers with rats. These actions were not only unethical but also contributed to the unsanitary conditions of the meat industry. The workers had grown accustomed to these disgusting practices, and thus, they did not even notice the rats being included in the meat they were consuming. column3: An ideal tragedy has to invoke pity and fear in those who watch it. It also needs to include a character who has suffered misfortune that wasn't totally deserved as a result of a lapse of judgement. It must also have a complex plot.
column4: An excellent tragedy needs to effectively evoke both pity and dread in its viewers. It should incorporate a character who has endured hardship that was not entirely deserved due to a lapse in judgment.

column3: An ideal tragedy would firstly be that the main protagonists tragic flaw is not some birth defect or physical ailment, but some fault of judgement that causes a dangerous or socially unacceptable flaw. Secondly,  an ideal tragedy should not have multple plots. The tragedy should have a singular issue that it addresses in response to the tragic flaw. Mutliple issues makes the tragedy less tragic and harder to relate to. Finally, the main protagonist should be someone who the audience can relate to, or at least understand. The audience should be able to relate to the short sightedness of the protagonist, and should at least be able to realize why what happened did, and that the same thing could very well happen to them personally. These three elements hold key roles in the ideal tragedy.
column4: Here is the passage reworded:  An ideal tragedy would be one in which the main character's tragic flaw is not caused by physical or biological abnormalities. It should consist of a single, overarching narrative that tackles a single central problem. Ideally, the main character should be relatable and the audience should be able to identify with the protagonist's shortsightedness. The tragedy should have a clear cause-and-effect relationship between the main character's flaw and the central problem.
